E più che un romanzo, questo libro è effettivamente un resoconto, una raccolta di impressioni su tutte le storie che la protagonista deve sorbirsi, convidivendo però quasi nulla di sé. Da una conversazione con il vicino di posto in aereo, a una cena con un'autrice, fino al corso di scrittura che sta tenendo, ogni occasione è solo il pretesto per riflettere sulla famiglia, il matrimonio, l'amore, la scrittura, il successo e la notorietà. review: A superb collection of short stories, whose most striking features are their simplicity and precision. Lucia Berlin's stories are infused with personaA superb collection of short stories, whose most striking features are their simplicity and precision. Lucia Berlin's stories are infused with personal and emotional recollections making the book more similar to auto-fiction. There is probably not a single job she didn't try at least once in her life. Incessantly moving since childhood and marrying three times, she was a nurse, a teacher, a cleaning woman and a receptionist, but what surfaces from most of the stories is her life-long struggle with alcoholism. A Manual for Cleaning Women is raw, unclouded and true-to-life. She's been compared to Carver and Čechov, but what I've seen more than once are strong thematic affinities with Jack Kerouac. We follow Berlin's women from San Francisco, to Arizona, Mexico, Chile, Texas, to New Mexico and Colorado, places in which Berlin herself has lived for years. One of the recurring characters is her sister Sally (not sure if that's her real name) and one of her sons, Ben - we meet them several times through the book in a cross-temporal narration. The only weakness is that sometimes the same characters will reappear but with different names, creating a certain confusion and a feeling of déjà-vu (are Carlotta and Dolores the same person?!). My main problem, though, was the language. I'm not a big fan of lyrical prose but I can appreciate it when it fits with the context. I even dreamed we snogged at a literary festival a couple of nights ago. But I can't deny I was expecting a bit more from these essays. They're not bad by any means, but not mind-blowing either, although we know that's not what Knausgård's writing is all about. Similarly to what he does in the Min Kamp series, here Knausgård begins every essay by describing and analysing a seemingly trivial object or situation to his unborn daughter - like plastic bags, chewing gums, beds, telephones - but this is merely a pretence to take a trip down memory lane, reaching unexpected conclusions. Some of these essays are really great (Daguerrotype, War, Oil tankers), some are quite touching (Fever, Rubber boots, Letter to an unborn daughter), some are very honest in a typical Knausgård style (when he describes what he likes to do with his now ex wife's wet labia), while others are quite banal (Eyes, Mouth, The migration of birds, Ambulances). I take off my clothes, peeling them away from my flesh like wallpaper. [...] My back is on the sand, my head rests against the rock, innocent as plankton; my hair spreads out, moving and fluid in the water. The earth rotates, holding my body down to it as it holds the moon; the sun pounds in the sky, red flames and rays pulsing from it, searing away the wrong form that encases me, dry rain soaking through me [...] When I am clean I come up out of the lake, leaving my false body floated on the surface, a cloth decoy. Surfacing is also a thought-provoking examination of how women were perceived in the 70s (just the 70s??). Anna, the other female character, can't go a day without makeup because her husband wants her to "look like a young chick all the time, if I don’t he gets mad". Also, everybody seems to hate the the pervasive menace, the Americans, who sometimes turn out be actual Canadians. "I leafed through all the men I had known to see whether or not I hated them. But then I realized it wasn’t the men I hated, it was the Americans, the human beings, men and women both. They’d had their chance but they had turned against the gods, and it was time for me to choose sides. I wanted there to be a machine that could make them vanish, a button I could press that would evaporate them without disturbing anything else, that way there would be more room for the animals, they would be rescued.".
